IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Now celebrating its 100th year of continuous service to low-income communities, LAS-ELC is a nationally-recognized non-profit that provides free legal assistance to low-income people facing employment- and public access-related issues throughout California.
IRS990.MissionDesc: LAS-ELCs mission is to advance justice and economic opportunity for poor and low-income people and their families at work, in school, and in the community. We use the full range of legal tools available to ensure all workers are afforded equal and fair treatment per local, state, and federal laws. Our staff and Board believe that work and workplace conditions are critical social determinants of health and work is essential to self-sufficiency, affords dignity, and facilitates civic engagement. LAS-ELC acts on these principles through a variety of strategies, including targeted community outreach and education; innovative partnerships with grassroots and public health entities; helplines; direct services clinics throughout the state; and administrative, court, or other representation. LAS-ELC serves diverse clients, many of whom experience illegal treatment because of their race, ethnicity, national origin, language preference/proficiency, gender, pregnancy, caregiving responsibilities,
IRS990.Desc: LAS-ELCs three largest legal service areas are Direct Services, Enforcement and Impact Litigation, and Outreach and Education.Direct ServicesIn 2015, LAS-ELC provided free legal information and counseling through clinics, helplines, and limited representation to approximately 3,500 indigent and low-income Californians. The Workers Rights Clinic (WRC) is the core of LAS-ELCs direct services offerings; in 2015 the WRC assisted more than 1,200 indigent workers. The WRC is a model program that has inspired other organizations and law schools to establish similar clinical programs. WRC clients are served by approximately 100 law students, 125 volunteer attorneys from the private labor and employment bar, and LAS-ELC staff. Trained student counselors conduct intakes, confer with supervising attorneys to analyze the problems, and then provide clients with information, suggest possible solutions, and make relevant referrals as appropriate. Counselors serve an additional and important function: to inform clients when they do not have legal recourse for their problem, while acknowledging clients expressed feelings that they were not treated fairly. WRCs generally operate weekday evenings in communities with underserved populations throughout California, including: San Francisco's Tenderloin neighborhood, the Berkeley/Oakland border, Fresno, Santa Ana (Orange County), Sacramento/Davis, Watsonville, and East Palo Alto, which was launched in 2015. A new San Diego location will open fall 2016. Workers unable to attend an in-person clinic are assisted via a weekly phone-in WRC. The WRC model relies on volunteers and partnerships with law schools and community organizations. Our WRC partners are: the University of California's Berkeley Law, Davis School of Law, Hastings College of the Law, and Irvine School of Law; Stanford School of Law; the University of the Pacific McGeorge School of Law; and the University of San Diego; as well as East Bay Community Law Center; Central California Legal Services; Legal Aid Society of Orange County; and the Watsonville Law Center, among others. In addition to the WRC, LAS-ELC conducts two specialized clinics: 1.Wage Claim Clinic (WCC): held at San Francisco and Oakland California Labor Commissioner's Office locations. The WCC helps victims of wage theft calculate unpaid wages and complete wage claim forms. In 2015, the WCC assisted 114 workers and represented 62 clients in Labor Commissioner's Office wage claim proceedings. WCC staff facilitated judgments or negotiated settlements totaling nearly $918,000 in recovered wages.2.Workers Rights Disability Law Clinic (WRDLC): held at the Ed Roberts Campus, a universally-accessible transit-oriented disability services hub in Berkeley. WRDLC services are tailored to the needs of clients with disabilities, who receive information, evaluation, advice, and representation when appropriate, on matters regarding reasonable accommodation and disability-based discriminatory treatment or practices. In 2015, the WRDLC clinic assisted 102 people.Also, LAS-ELC operates three helplines:1.Chinese Language Helpline: assisted more than 1,000 monolingual or LEP Cantonese and Mandarin speakers in 2015. 2.Project SURVIVE Helpline: assisted more than 200 survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault, or stalking in 2015. 3.Work & Family Helpline: assisted more than 1,380 pregnant women, new parents, workers with serious health conditions, and caregivers in 2015.Lastly, through limited representation, attorneys assist individual clients with specific matters that might include: requesting personnel files, drafting demand letters, negotiating informal settlements, assisting clients draft and file charges with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Department of Fair Employment and Housing, and representing workers in pre- litigation settlement conferences and mediations. Enforcement and Impact LitigationLAS-ELCs docket includes enforcement cases that vindicate an individual worker's right to unpaid wages, a reasonable accommodation for a disability, a work environment free of discrimination, a medical leave to care for an ill parent, or the right to return to a position after taking parenting leave. These cases keep employers accountable, re-enforce the strength laws, and importantly, make a tangible difference in our clients lives.LAS-ELC also litigates cases that have a broad impact across a community, a geographic area, an industry, or a large employer. For example: 1)Our client, Mr. Guerrero, was brought to the U.S. as a child and as a teenager had been given an invalid Social Security number to work and help support his family. Years later, he was naturalized and applied to work as a correctional officer with the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR). His application was rejected twice because he honestly answered the question, Have you ever had or used a social security number other than the one you used on this questionnaire? LAS-ELC litigated Mr. Guerrero's case; the district court ruled in Mr. Guerrero's favor and found CDCRs question and practice of using it to disqualify applicants had a disparate impact on Latinosa violation of federal law (Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964). This case is significant because it addresses employers increasing use of questions that appear non-discriminatory, yet in fact have disproportionate adverse impacts on protected groups. 2)Castle Park High School is in a low-income, predominantly Latino area of San Diego County. The school's female softball players had limited opportunities to participate in sports and had to make do with rundown and bare-bones facilities in comparison to the state-of-the art boys baseball fields, locker rooms, and training facilities. LAS-ELC litigated a class action over many years, challenging the district's failure to comply with federal law (Title IX) that guarantees equal opportunities for girls in school-sponsored sports. The girls prevailed. And, the district is required to . . . comply with Title IX in all aspects of its athletic programs and activities. The case is believed to be one of the first that applied Title IX to public school districts, whereas most cases have been brought against colleges and universities. LAS-ELC enforces Title IX because the skills that young women gain from sports participation, including teamwork, leadership, and discipline, significantly contribute to later success in higher education and employment.Outreach and EducationLAS-ELC believes that educating low-wage workers about workplace rights can protect them from abuse and gives them agency to advocate for their workplace rights. We produce more than 100 print and online Know Your Rights or Do It Yourself resources, including videos, which collectively cover a wide variety of legal rights topics relevant to low-income workers and their families. In addition to the many resources available on our website, www.las-elc.org, we post clinic schedules and links to other helpful websites and sister social and legal services organizations. LAS-ELCs website meets standards for visually-impaired users and most of our resources are available in Spanish and Chinese; many are also available in Filipino and Vietnamese.One unique outreach and education project reaches the Bay Area's large monolingual or LEP Cantonese and Mandarin-speaking community. Our Language Access Coordinator 1) produces a weekly Know Your Rights column in Sing Tao Daily, the nation's largest Chinese-language daily; and 2) hosts two weekly employment-related Q&A segments on two major Chinese community radio stations, AM 1400 KEST (Cantonese) and FM 96.1 KSQQ (Mandarin). Together the stations reach an estimated 515,000 Chinese speakers each week.LAS-ELC staff also conduct in-person outreach and education in specific client communities through presentations. For example, an attorney who focuses on female immigrant workers in the greater Fresno area held a workshop, with an interpreter, for workers who speak an indigenous Oaxacan language. This community is particularly underserved by social and legal services because they speak neither English nor Spanish. Veterans are another example of a community with serious workplace challenges; an LAS-ELC project has been building relationships with veteran communities throughout California and has held pop-up clinics at stand down events for women veterans. Staff also conduct outreach and assist veterans who have post-traumatic stress or are survivors of military sexual trauma that need workplace accommodations and often face discrimination. Additionally, LAS-ELCs trainings to social and health services providers on employment rights relevant to their constituencies. This train the trainer approach harnesses the trusted provider-client relationship. We have been using this model for more than a decade with domestic violence and sexual assault services providers, and over the last few years ha

Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.ExplanationTxt: Schedule A, Part II, Section A Public Support, Line 1Excluded Unusual GrantsCypres Awards: $375,472

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Organization has evaluated its current tax positions as of December 31, 2015 and is not aware of any significant uncertain tax positions for which a reserve would be necessary

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The LAS-ELC provides matching grants to student law clerks who are chosen for full-time summer positions with the LAS-ELC after an extensive interview process . After offers are accepted, the human resources staff reviews each student's available funding and allocates budgeted grant funds. The LAS-ELC's policy is to match grants that the students receive from other sources, such as law school public interest organizations and federal work/study programs, so that its summer clerks are equitably compensated.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 1a: Explanation of Delegated Broad Authority to Committee
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: By resolution on 5/26/11 the Board of Directors ratified and confirmed that it had in the past and continued to delegate authority to the Executive Committee to act on its behalf in all matters except those specified in that resolution. At year-end 2015 the Executive Committee had 27 members.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b: Form 990 Review Process
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The LAS-ELC 990 is prepared by the auditor, with information provided by the Finance Director and Chief Operating Officer. During the drafting process the 990 isreviewed by the Finance Director, Chief Operating Officer, and President. Uponcompletion of the final draft, the 990 is presented to the Audit Committee of theBoard for review, comment and approval and to the full Board. The Chief OperatingOfficer, Finance Director, and Finance Manager respond to any questions posed by Audit Committee members, and obtain the Committee's approval. The chair of the Audit Committee reports to the Board of Directors at the appropriate quarterly meeting regarding the substance and completion of the 990 filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c: Explanation of Monitoring and Enforcement of Conflicts
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Each director signs the following statement upon election to the Board. Signed statements are kept in the LAS-ELC offices.Adopted by the Board of Directors on July 30, 2009:We, the Directors of the Legal Aid Society Employment Law Center, resolve that no member of the Board of Directors shall participate in any discussion or vote on any matter in which he or she or a member of his or her immediate family has potential conflict of interest due to having material economic involvement regarding the matter being discussed. When such a situation presents itself, the director must announce his or her potential conflict, disqualify him or herself, and be excused from the meeting until discussion is over on the matter involved. The President or Chair of the meeting is expected to make inquiry if such conflict appears to exist and the board member has not made it known.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15a: Compensation Review & Approval Process - CEO, Top Management
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Refer to description in 15b of Compensation Committee process.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15b: Compensation Review and Approval Process for Officers and Key Employees
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The LAS-ELC's Compensation Committee is comprised of at least three members of the Board of Directors who are not related to and not subject to the control of the individuals whose compensation the Committee reviews, and who are free of any relationship that would interfere with their exercise of independent judgment as a committee member. The committee annually reviews, approves and recommends to the Executive Committee the annual compensation levels, benefits and retirement programs of the President and other key individuals who are deemed to be Disqualified Persons. In order to establish reasonable compensation levels, the committee engages in the following process: Assesses the nature and scope of each position under its review. Considers factors which might be referenced in setting compensation for each individual in such positions; including for example, exceptional performance, additional duties, unique background, relevant experiences, personal skills, and particular abilities. The committee also considers the business challenges facing the organization that require the use of these or other attributes or skills. Obtains appropriate and comparable compensation market data, including data on the following: compensation of similarly situated organizations, both for-profit and tax-exempt, for functionally comparable positions nature and scope of benefits and retirement programs; the location of the organization; the availability of similar specialists in the geographic area; compensation surveys by recognized independent firms.The Committee documents the basis for its determination of reasonable compensation by including an assessment of the individual's contribution to the LAS-ELC, and the basis for determining that the individual's compensation was reasonable in light of that evaluation and the market data.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19: Other Organization Documents Publicly Available
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Financial statements are available upon request and on LAS-ELC's website.
